talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that, early in February, part of an airstrip at Mascot overseas terminal collapsed under the weight of a Super Constellation aircraft?
Is it a fact that some little time earlier parts of the main runway at Eagle Farm airport, in Brisbane, cracked under the weight of DC6 aeroplanes?

Is it a fact that some of the sections of the runways affected were built in the last few years to a standard which, it was claimed, would carry heavier aeroplanes than those which have used these airports up to the present time?
Was any investigation made into these serious happenings; if so, with what result?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: A Super Constellation caused damage to the apron hut not the airstrip outside the overseas terminal building at Mascot. No damage was caused to the aircraft.
The continued operation of DC6 and other aircraft at Eagle Farm airport caused deterioration of the main runway.
The pavements affected by this aircraft were constructed a considerable number of years ago and were not built to carry the wheel loads imposed by aircraft being used at the present time.

The Department of Civil Aviation and the Department of Works naturally made an investigation into these occurrences which were, however, not unexpected. Before both happenings, plans were in hand to strengthen the pavements; in each case the funds have been provided and work commenced on the construction of new runways at Eagle Farm. The apron at Mascot which was affected will bekept in operation by continuous maintenance during the life of the present overseas terminal. It is not intended to reconstruct the whole of this pavement since in the final development of Mascot the area will not be used as an apron but as part of the building area.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that the Papua-New Guinea Administration has been endeavouring to establish the production of kenaf fibre on a commercial basis?
Was an expert brought from the United States of America to advise the Administration in respect of this project?

Is it a fact that this expert protested to the Department of Territories, and to the Minister, regarding what he declares to have been neglect by the Administration in following his advice, and which neglect, he states, resulted in considerable financial loss to the Commonwealth?
If the facts are as stated will he make a statement of the details?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: In accordance with government policy, the Administration of Papua and New Guinea has been carrying out experimental work on kenaf and also co-operating with private interests in larger-scale trials with the object of finding out whether commercial production of kenaf would be feasible.

An American expert was brought from the United States of America in 1952 to advise upon the development of the fibre industry in Papua and New Guinea. In 1954 the same expert was brought out jointly by the private interests and the Administration (the costs being shared) to advise on the use of decorticating machinery and the latest developments elsewhere in growing and processing kenaf.

No. No protest was made by the expert to the Department of Territories and to the Minister for Territories. An article purporting to give views of the expert appeared in the South Pacific Post of 3rd March, 1954. In a letter dated6th April,1954, to the Secretary, Department of Territories, the expert wrote: "The article was, in my opinion, erroneous and I was misquoted".
See answer to 3.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: What amount of money has been provided by the Commonwealth with respect to the recent disastrous floods in New South Wales and Queensland for (a) immediate relief and (b) rehabilitation?
Is it intended to do anything further; if so, what are the details?
Has the Government any plans to deal with the problem of flood prevention and alleviation; if so, will he state what they are?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable members questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: In the case of the floods in New South Wales, the Commonwealth agreed to a request by the State Government to provide up to £375,000 on a £1-for-£1 basis with the State for the relief of personal hardship. Because of the catastrophic proportions of the New South Wales floods, the Commonwealth also agreed to meet half the cost of grants up to £1,000,000 made by the State Government to assist local authorities in the restoration of works and services damaged by the floods. In respect of the floods in Queensland, the Commonwealth has agreed in principle to contribute on a £1-for-£1 basis with the State Government towards the relief of personal hardship, and is awaiting advice from the State Government of the estimated amount required for that purpose.
The planning of flood preventive measures, and the priorities to be accorded such projects in State works programmes, are essentially matters for the State governments.
